comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: From the list of Soldiers Died in the Great War: Name:Herbert William Burrows Birth Place:London Residence:Giggleswick-in-craven, Yorks Death Date:17 Sep 1916 Death Location:France & Flanders Enlistment Location:Helmsley, Yorks Rank:Rifleman Regiment:King's Royal Rifle Corps Battalion:21st Battalion Number:C/12372 Type of Casualty:Killed in action Theatre of War:Western European Theatre Medal Roll Index Card shows his rank as A Cpl and gives a correspondence address as 341 Blarney Street, Cork. His name appears on the war memorial for Giggleswick www.cpgw.org.uk/craven_war_memorial.cfm?mCode=GIGGLESW&am... Photo of 7 Platoon B Company appears on this website 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=151... and shows Cpl Burrows 8th from left. Birth Index shows a birth registered in Chelsea in Dec Q 1896.

comment.author: 69798423@N03
comment._content:
The 41st Division took part in the Battle of Flers-Coucelette on 15th September 1916. They actually faced the village of Flers with the 122nd (Left) and 124th (Right) Brigades in the frontline. 

The 124th Brigade had the 10th Queens and the 21 KRRC leading the attack and the brigade was given the task of turning right after Flers to move onto Guedecourt. The front waves formed up in no man's land and they advanced behind a creeping barrage. Some of the men were so eager that they were killed by their own barrage. 

The 124th Brigade managed to capture Tea Support and the Switch Line by 7 a.m. and by 7.20 a.m. Flers Trench had also fell with parties of the brigade moving onto their third objective. 

This brigade was unable to move much further than this. By 3.20 p.m. around 200 men from both the 10th Queens and the 21st KRRC made one more attampt to move onto Bulls Road led by Lt Col Oakley and the Earl of Faversham. The brigade commnader also ordered two companies of the 23rd Middlesex to support them. 

In this advance the Earl of Faversham was killed but they managed to occupy the western edge of Bulls Road and make contact with the 122nd Brigade. Any further advance on Gird trench was stopped by machine gun fire. They held here and all further attacks for the day were stopped. Counter attacks were stopped by what was by now a very weak 124th Brigade and they were eventually relieved by the 123rd Brigade which began to take over the whole of the 41st Division's front.

comment.author: 73313451@N00
comment._content: It appears the witness to his oath was his tutor Reverend J P Brocklehurst. Who was also the name in receipt of his personal effects and medals after his death too, makes me wonder what his relationship with his father the major was like.
